title-group.article-title: Design, modeling and stability control for an actuated dynamic walking planar bipedal robot

article-meta.aff: 1Department and Graduate School of Computer Science, National Pingtung University of Education, Taiwan
2Global Earth Observation and Data Analysis Center (GEODAC), National Cheng Kung University, Taiwan
3Department of Information Management, National Kaohsiung First University of Science and Technology, Taiwan

author-notes.corresp: Chen-Yuan Chen, Department and Graduate School of Computer Science, National Pingtung University of Education, No. 4–18, Ming Shen Road, Pingtung 90003, Taiwan Email: cyc@mail.npue.edu.tw

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Research studies about biped robots are abundant in the areas of bionic mechanism design, walking patterns, walking trajectories, movement balance, and control theory, etc. In recent years there have been many studies about bipedal robots. The main purpose of this current study is how to produce the essential structure of a biped walking robot. The modules needed to ensure the stability of the robot as it is walking are discussed. In addition, the formula to find the balanced kinematics for a bipedal walking robot that will enable it to keep its balance while moving is addressed.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Intelligent control is becoming a more common tool in many engineering and industrial applications. These control algorithms are also used for fuzzy logic, genetic algorithms (GA) and neural networks (NN). All methods of intelligent control have the following features: learning ability and adaptability; robustness; a simple control algorithm for relatively user-friendly human–machine interfacing. As a consequence, practical applications of these systems have been increasing, such asrobot manipulation, engineering application and construction managements (Hsiao et al., 2005a,b,c,d,e; Chen et al., 2005a,b, 2006a,b,c, 2007a,b,c,d,e,f,g, 2008a,b,c,d,e, 2009a,b,c,d,e,f, 2010a,b,c,d,e,f,g,h, 2011a,b,c,d,e,f,g,h, 2012a,b,c,d; Chen, 2006, 2010a,b,c 2011a,b,c,d,e,f,g,h,i, 2012a,b,c; Hsieh et al., 2006; Tsai et al., 2008; Yang et al., 2008a,b; Yeh et al., 2008, 2012; Almutairi and Zribi, 2009; Amini and Vahdani, 2009; Lin et al., 2009a,b, 2011a,b, 2012a,b; Guclu and Metin, 2009; Lin and Chao, 2009; Omurlu et al., 2009; Tu et al., 2009; Tusset et al., 2009; Zhao et al., 2009; Chen and Chen, 2010a,b; Chen and Saif, 2010; Chiang et al., 2010; Lee et al., 2010a,b, 2011a,b,c; Li et al., 2010; Lin and Chen, 2010, 2011; Solihin et al., 2010; Shih et al., 2010a,b,c,d, 2011a,b,c,d; Chen and Huang, 2011; Cheng et al., 2011; Chiang and Wang, 2011; Chiou et al., 2011; Chu et al., 2011, 2012; Jayaswal et al., 2011; Kuo and Chen, 2011, 2012a,b; Kuo et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2011a,b, 2012a,b; Marichal et al., 2011; Metin and Guclu, 2011; Soundarrajan and Sumathi, 2011; Shen et al., 2011; Tang et al., 2011; Tsai and Chen, 2011a,b; Yu et al., 2011a,b; Lee and Chen, 2012; Su et al., 2012; Tseng and Chen, 2012; Tseng et al., 2012a,b,c; Chen 2009a,b; Hsu et al., 2011; Shih et al., 2011). Over the past few years, there have been significant efforts devoted to researching system analysis and control designs. Undoubtedly, the Lyapunov theory is one of the most common approaches dealing with the stability analysis of systems. However ithas been necessary to develop more effective measures to overcome the conservatism that arises from the use of dynamic methods. There are many important issues that require study related to control systems, such as time delays, GA and robustness.

Certainly, robotic control is an important role and more and more studies have been carried out to show how the robot can autonomously avoid obstacles to effectively arrive at its destination. For example, Chen et al. (2011a) proposed an interesting method to implement an autonomous humanoid robot (the ARSR) comprised of the Lego NXT Intelligent Bricks. Chen et al. (2011b) provided a contribution describing the mechanical construction of a low-cost bipedal mechanism, as well as the path record system of a biped surveillance robot for indoor reconnaissance tasks. Shih et al. (2011a) proposed a decision tree method to decide upon one behavior from three possible types of movement: walk forward, turn left and turn right. Meanwhile, three experiments have been carried out to show how the robot can autonomously avoid obstacles to effectively arrive at its destination. Shih (2011b) et al. again proposed a novel path-planning method for multilink manipulators along the shortest path against obstacles in the plane. Reducing time complexity and information size, the proposed greedy algorithm by Shih et al. has good effectiveness in path-planning problems. In this study, we present a kind of bipedal robot. This bipedal robot will be used to implement the function of dynamic walking. The contribution of this paper is to detail the modules on the design, modeling and stability control for an actuated dynamic walking planar bipedal robot.

sec.title: 2. Assemblage
sec.p: Before assembling robots, the components from which they are composed should be realized. Even the kinds of screws and brackets used in assembly are important.

sec.title: 2.1. Modules
sec.p:
An aluminum U-shaped bracket is utilized as being close in shape to the human knee. When the upside and downside are connected to the Servo, it allows the robot’s legs to bend and allows many kinds of poses. An aluminum Servo Bracket fixed to the framework of the sustaining servomechanism is equivalent to human bone that holds the muscles. The servomechanism (hereafter Servo) is used to provide mechanical control of a desired manipulation through the use of feedback. The aluminum Foot Bracket functions like the sole of the foot, supporting the body and enabling the robot to stand firmly on the ground (see the assembled parts in Figure 1). During assembly, each bracket should be assembled either from top to bottom or from bottom to top in order to avoid mixing up the components. It should be noticed that there are two sizes of aluminum U-shaped bracket used: one is 27 mm and the other is 22 mm (Figure 2 shows a comparison between the two different sizes). From the top, the 27 mm brackets are mounted in the second and the sixth positions on the Servo (as shown in Figure 3), the brackets at the rest of the positions are set to be 22 mm. Figure 1.
Assembled parts (each part is composed like this).
Figure 2.
Left side is 22 mm, right side is 27 mm.
Figure 3.
Assembled robot (the 27 mm aluminum U-shaped Brackets appear in the second and sixth positions).

sec.title: 2.2. Actuated motor
sec.p:
The Servo functions like the muscles of a human being and can make a robot perform many different actions. During assembly, the motor should be mounted on the aluminum Servo Bracket in the last step. Since many screws and nuts are needed to lock the aluminum Servo Bracket into place, it is difficult if the Servo is set into place first. The Servo Extension Cable, the connecting lines for the Servo and Servo Runner A, must be assembled first. Then the power source can be turned on. Inthis way we can avoid damaging the Servo by a surge in power. It is important when using the Servo for the first time to turn on the power source to make sure that it is running. When the Servo stops running, it will become the central point. Now the white turntable on the Servo has to be dismantled and then reassembled so that the holes in the up-down-left-right-center positions will be linked to form a straight-cross shape. This action is called adjustment (the lower picture in Figure 4 presents the adjusted condition). This is done to avoid inaccuracy of angles during operation. Figure 4.
The upper photograph shows the non-adjusted position, and the lower picture the adjusted position.

sec.title: 3. Behavior control
sec.p: After assembling the robot, the kind of movement to be carried out by each structure should be realized first. In other words, it must be understood which Servo or Bracket must be controlled or must move to obtain the desired aim. The largest angle of motion carried by the robot also needs to be understood and limited. Otherwise, the joints of the robot can be easily burned out by transferring over-sized angles. The operation of the robot is directed by computer software, which helps to control the different kinds of angles, poses and actions carried out by the robot.

The upper part of the robot is composed of Basic Commander 1 (BC1), Servo Runner A, the Command Board, a Servo Power Line, the Command Board Power Line, the command (hereafter CMD) bus, a Servo Extension Cable (positions are shown Figure 5). The CMD bus is provided for a connection between the Servo Runner A and the Command Board. The BC1 is basically a small-scale IC that can be regarded as the nerve center of the whole robot. Saving the program downloaded from a USB port is its main function. Since the BC1’s mounting is quite fragile, dismantling them is not suggested when they are set on the Command Board. The cmdBUS connects the Command Board and Servo Runner A and is in charge of delivering messages from the BC1 to Servo Runner A. Figure 5.
Left part shows Servo Runner A; the right part is the Command Board.

In fact, the Command Board can be seen as the main part, while Servo Runner A is a node. A robot might have many nodes for managing different functions. For instance, Servo Runner A is in charge of controlling a motor. If the robot is required to have the function of detecting obstacles, a set of boards with the function of sending and receiving acoustic waves will also be required. These boards also need to be mounted on the Command Board. The Command Board can support at most seven sets of boards.

The Servo Power Line supplies the main power source to the robot and is connected with Servo Runner A. It can be wired not only by an electric power source but also with batteries to allow the robot to walk in any environment. There are two ways to supply power to the Command Board – by a computer connected by a USB cable or by connecting Servo Runner A to a Command Board Power Line. The Servo Extension Cable is part of the connection with the Servo. Servo Runner A can support at most 16 Servos. The lower part is composed of the Aluminum Servo Bracket, Aluminum U-shaped Bracket, Aluminum Foot Bracket, Servo (see the positions presented in Figure 6). The Forward kinematics of the biped walking robot can be determined based on kinematics theory using the following equations: (1)ii-1A=Tz,dTz,θTx,aTx,a=[cosθi-cosαisinθisinαicosθiaicosθisinθicosαisinθi-sinαicosθiaicosθi0sinαicosαidi0001] (2)[ii-1A]-1=[cosθisinθiθi-ai-cosαisinθicosαisinθisinαi-disinαisinαicosθ-sinαicosθicosαi-dicosαi0001] (3)i0T=Πj=1iAjj-1=[XiYiZiPi0001]=[Ri0Pi001] Figure 6.
Lower part is the joint area.

sec.title: 4. Discussion
sec.p: The Aluminum Foot Bracket can bend left and right about 45 degrees. Unlike human beings, it cannot bend around 80 degrees forward, backward, left or right. Thealuminum U-shaped Bracket is a vital component allowing the robot to bend. It can move about 180 degrees. However, it is suggested that the Aluminum U-shaped Brackets should not be allowed to collide with each other. This might disrupt the motion of the robot, but more seriously, it might cause the joints to stop rotating. If this happens and the Servo keeps working it could burn out.

In the present study, the Aluminum Servo Bracket supports the Servo. However, there is a big defect associated with these brackets. The two Aluminum Servo Brackets allow bending by the Aluminum U-shaped Bracket. However, if the extent of the bending is too much they will collide with each other. Hence, the motion of the robot is limited, meaning it cannot act as freely as can a human being.

Another problem is that the Servo has a limited lifetime. During the course of this research, 12 Servos were used. Their temperature was monitored by noting when they were warm to the touch. As soon as they overheat, the power must be turned off to allow them to cool. Even if the overheating is not serious it will impact the execution of movement. For example, if it is necessary to transfer 45 degrees of motion but the Servo is overheated, it will only transfer 10 degrees. More seriously, it might cause the Servo to burn out, a condition indicated by the Servo belching smoke, or smell whether there is a scorched smell. As mentioned above, if the range of motion of the two Aluminum U-shaped Brackets is too great, this keeps the Servo working, and might make it burn out more easily, which should be avoided.

sec.title: 5. Conclusions
sec.p: The study of bipedal robots involves an understanding of the mechanism, mechanics, electronic engineering, control engineering, bio-engineering, robotics, and so on. In the process of assembling robots, each component should be differentiated. It is important even to note that each component should be fastened by the appropriate screws. Screws must be fastened to avoid a bracket falling off as the robot is walking. Each time the robot is stored, it should be ensured that its joints are straight. That is, a robot must be stored standing in order to avoid damage or wear on the Servo. During assembly, if two different sized Aluminum U-shaped Brackets are set in the wrong positions, it could cause a difference in length between the right and left legs,which might damage the other brackets while walking.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors are grateful for the financial support from their funding bodies and are also most grateful for the kind assistance of Professor Ali Nayfeh, Editor of JVC, and for the constructive suggestions from the anonymous reviewers, allof which has led to the making of several corrections and have greatly aided us to improve the presentation of this paper.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by research grants from the National Science Council, Republic of China to Dr. Chen-Yuan Chen (grant nos. NSC 99-2628-E-153-001, and NSC 100-2628-E-153-001).
